description.title: Equatorial to Horizontal (Alt-Az) Transform
description.what: Converts celestial RA/Dec to local azimuth/altitude for a ground observer, using sidereal time and spherical trigonometry.
description.why: This is the 'where do I point my telescope?' calculation. Accuracy depends on the GAST (sidereal time) model used.
description.units: Angular separation in arcseconds between reference and candidate az/alt positions.
description.interpret: Lower separation = better. Differences mainly arise from GAST model choice.

alignment.time_input: JD (Julian Date), TT scale for precession/nutation, UT1 for sidereal time
alignment.time_scales: TT for BPN matrix; UT1≈TT-69.184s simplified
alignment.leap_seconds: not applicable (JD input, no UTC conversion in this experiment)

library_notes.astropy: The 'astropy' adapter calls ERFA/pyerfa C kernels directly from Python. Accuracy results are identical to ERFA. Performance results measure Python-loop + ERFA-kernel overhead, NOT the high-level astropy.coordinates stack.

models.erfa: Spherical trig via eraHd2ae / eraAe2hd; GAST via eraGst06a; no refraction
models.siderust: Spherical trig matching ERFA formulas; GAST IAU 2006 via siderust astro path
models.astropy: eraHd2ae / eraAe2hd via bundled ERFA; GAST via eraGst06a
models.libnova: ln_get_hrz_from_equ / ln_get_equ_from_hrz; convention fix: az_erfa = (360 - az_ln + 180) % 360
models.anise: Not available in ANISE adapter for this experiment

alignment.accuracy_interpretation: accuracy vs ERFA reference (same spherical trig model)
alignment.note: Azimuth convention: ERFA 0°=North CW; libnova 0°=South. All adapters use the same spherical trig, differences arise from GAST model. No atmospheric refraction applied.
